question_text: A 50-year-old woman is evaluated for a pigment change in her fingernail.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is melanonychia (Option C), a longitudinal brown pigmentation of the nail plate. Melanonychia can be a normal variant in persons with darker skin tones, but it may also occur as a result of systemic disease, medication, infection, or an underlying melanocytic lesion, such as malignant melanoma. Findings concerning for melanoma include a broad base with tapering at the free edge; disruption of the nail plate; pigment extending onto the proximal nailfold or hyponychium; and longitudinal, irregular melanonychia on a single nail.
